Description: unique ID of a paper
unique ID of an effect size (i.e. assigning a number to each line of the data set)
detailed reference, including title
first author and year, regardless of number of authors
whether the study appeared in a peer-reviewed journal ('yes') or not ('no')

unique sample ID within one paper
e.g. the same sample can make for several observations (lines), for example when the same sample was measured various times (e.g. panel study) or the same sample makes for several measures (e.g. for different levels of 'news_family')
unique sample ID across all papers (achieved by combining paperID and sampleID)
country where the study was conducted
country names corrected so that they are compatible with map data for plots
version of country with fewer levels (levels: `US`, `non-US`).
continent

Regarding the factor news veracity (i.e. true vs. fake news):
between  = between two groups of participants (i.e one group only saw fake news, another group only saw true news)
within = within one group of participants (i.e. participants saw both Fake AND True news)
whether study was online ('yes') or else ('no')

Whether news have been selected after having been pre-tested for perceived accuracy (to ensure their discernment, i.e. that true news will be rated as more accurate than fake news). Code pre-tested materials as 'yes';  sometimes, researches did not explicitly test items for perceived accuracy but describe how implicitly it was a seleciton criterion (e.g. to avoid ceiling effects, or selecting 'plausible' news items), case in which code 'implicit_selection';  else code 'no'

if pre-tested = 'yes', describe what the pre-test was like; even if pre-tested = 'no' but researchers describe how they selected news (e.g. avoid ceiling effects, select 'plausible' true news etc.), use this variable to describe the news selection

Variable: Stimuli for main condtion (true news vs. fake news)

Description: whether a set of news items has been used in another paper we already coded ('recycled') or not ('original'), or partly (`partly`)
if `recycled_news` == ('recycled') or  ('partly'), indicates reference of source
Who selected the news items? (mostly 'researchers', but can also take other levels)
How were fake news items selected? (almost always 'fact-checking websites')
How were true news items selected?(often 'mainstream media', but can also be otherwise, e.g. 'fact-checking websites')
What 'family' of news wer selected? Can be anything, e.g. 'political', 'environment', 'covid' etc.

version of news_family with only three levels: `political` (including concordant vs. discordant), `covid` and `other` (historical; environment/health/science/ /militar). The baseline for the regression will be `political`
Binary variable with two levels (contained in `news_family` variable; levels: `politically_concordant`  and `politically_discordant`)
unique sample ID across all papers (achieved by combining paperID and sampleID)

sometimes, participants see a selection of a pool of news -- if this is the case, report this number here;
Code the news_pool with respect to "news_family": e.g. when politically concordant and discordant news were drawn from a total pool of 24 (in which both occur with equal frequency), code only '12' as news pool in the respective rows.
Share of true news among all news (true news *plus* fake news) that participants saw (typically it's 0.5)
which format was the news presented  in
version of news_format with fewer levels (levels: `headline`, `headline_picture`, `headline_picture_lede`)
whether participants were provided a news source or not (levels: `TRUE`, `FALSE`)
Type of proxy measure used to assess accuracy (e.g. accuracy, credibility, believability, trustworthiness, trust)
Details of the type of the exact question used to assess accuracy measure; be as specific as possible
accuracy_measure but as a numeric variable (used to do calculations)
grouped version of accuracy_measure (levels: binary vs. 4-point vs. 6-point vs. 7-point vs. other, for all other numeric scales that were not frequent)

Perfectly symmetrical scales include all binary scales (e.g. “True” or “False”, “Real” or “Fake”, is accurate “Yes” or “No”, is accurate and unbiased  “Yes” or “No”), and most Likert-scales (e.g. 1 to 7: “Definitely fake” [1] to “Definitely real” [7]). The most common scale, a 4-point Likert scale ([1] not at all accurate, [2] not very accurate, [3] somewhat accurate, [4] very accurate) however, is not perfectly symmetrical (the lower end point is more extreme than the upper endpoint).

Variable: Info on treatment (experimental conditions/manipulation beyond the fake news/true news distinction) if tested

Description: indicates whether the treatment was intended to increase discernment (most of the cases, e.g. literacy interventions) in which case code 'positive' or whether it was negative (few cases, e.g. time pressure) in which case code 'negative'
Details about the exact manipulation compared to the control conditon; be as specific as possible
Details about the correlate variable; be as specific as possible
observations are instances of news ratings (n_subj multiplied by n_news)
mean of participants' fake news ratings

we calculate an error for fake and true news separately, which we define as the distance of participant's actual ratings to the best possible ratings. For fake news, that is the bottom of the scale (or 0, on a binary scale). For true news, that is the top of the scale (or 1, on a binary scale).
standard deviation (SD) of participants' fake news ratings
mean of participants' true news ratings

we calculate an error for fake and true news separately, which we define as the distance of participant's actual ratings to the best possible ratings. For fake news, that is the bottom of the scale (or 0, on a binary scale). For true news, that is the top of the scale (or 1, on a binary scale).
standard deviation (SD) of participants' true news ratings

takes on value "raw data" if we downloaded the raw data and calculated the summary statistics ourselves, or "paper" if we relied on summary statistics that were reported in the paper, or "authors" if we contacted the authors and they provided the relevant summary statistics to us.
whehter the study measured long-term effects of interventions. Code 'panel' if at least one sample within the paper is measured at (at least) two different points in time, else code 'no'
notes on the paper/effect size
